text: What are your thoughts on Latin America,
where we still face significant challenges
in terms of educational quality

and, unfortunately,
inequality gaps,

even though Uruguay
shows better metrics?

What role does technology
play in these processes

when considering the broader
development of society?
Contrary to what people may think,
successful technologies are the ones
that make us more human

or, at the very least, enhance
and support very human traits.

For example, when
we consider WhatsApp,

some might believe it has
hindered face-to-face conversations

because we're
engrossed in our phones.

However, when we're
glued to our screens,

we're still engaged in
communication with someone.
It may not be in person,

but technology elevates our
social interactions to a new level.

I firmly believe that technology
helps us become more human.

Now, the greatest challenge
is not leaving anyone behind

and ensuring that no one is
excluded from these advancements.

That's why education is
of paramount importance.

Throughout Uruguay's history,
every time we've invested in education,

something beneficial has materialized
twenty years down the road.

In the 1960s, the university
dean made the bold decision

to invest one million dollars
to buy IBM computers.

Think about it:
it was 1968,

with the May '68 events in France
and Fidel Castro in Cuba,

and yet they installed a
computer at the university.

This very choice
laid the foundation

for a thriving software
industry in the '80s or '90s.

Initiatives like
"One Laptop per Child" have ensured

that schoolchildren could navigate
the challenges of the pandemic
without major issues.

Education requires
these long-term investments.
